articles.title: Bulgaria, Greece, Romania and EC signed a memorandum on the development of transport infrastructure between the three countries
articles.summary: The new connections will be essential for supplies and for the transfer of troops and equipment from Greece to Moldova and Ukraine, said European Commissioner Apostolos Dzidzicostas
articles.content:
The new connections will be essential for supplies and for the transfer of troops and equipment from Greece to Moldova and Ukraine, said European Commissioner Apostolos Dzidzicostas

BRUSSELS – Bulgaria, Greece, Romania and the European Commission signed in Brussels a memorandum of cooperation on the development of transport infrastructure in the region. On behalf of Bulgaria the document was signed by the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Transport and Communications Grozdhan Karadzhov.

This is a turning point for our region and for Europe. For decades the idea of completing the north-south axis has remained only on paper, said Minister Karadzhov.

He added that the signing of the memorandum is not a symbolic act, but a promise to open new trade routes, to overcome congestion at the borders, and to increase European resilience.

According to him, new bridges over the Danube are needed because they are important for the entire continent, not only for the three countries in the memorandum. The Deputy Prime Minister noted that the expansion of the transport network in the region will also contribute to military mobility and will open up opportunities for investment.

The European Commissioner for Transport Apostolos Dzidzikostas pointed out that the three countries have chosen to deepen their cooperation and with this, in his words, the area between the Black and Aegean Seas will no longer be a European periphery.

The new transport links will be of essential importance for supply chains and for the transfer of troops and equipment, extending from Greece to Moldova and Ukraine, said Commissioner Dzidzikostas.

He added that a new bridge over the Danube at Ruse will contribute to mobility opportunities in the EU and NATO. Dzidzikostas explained that by the end of 2026 a plan with funding will be prepared for the projects under the next multiannual EU budget. He added that the memorandum will be politically binding. According to him, the future projects will provide the most strategic transport links in Southeast Europe. (3.12.2025)
articles.reasoning: The memorandum signed by Bulgaria, Greece, Romania, and the European Commission to develop transport infrastructure represents a significant, tangible step towards improving regional connectivity, trade, and military mobility. This has broad implications for European resilience, supply chains, and strategic cooperation, benefiting many people in Southeast Europe and beyond. The article provides sufficient context about the scope, impact, and future plans, making it a meaningful positive development.

**Impact** – This agreement will open new trade routes, reduce border delays, and improve how supplies and military equipment can move from Greece to Moldova and Ukraine. The new infrastructure will strengthen Europe’s ability to respond to challenges and support NATO operations. It also encourages investment in the region and makes Southeast Europe less isolated.

**What’s next step** – By the end of 2026, the European Commission will prepare a detailed plan with funding for these projects as part of the next EU budget. The memorandum makes the cooperation politically binding, meaning the countries promise to follow through on these improvements.

articles.title: Rural regions fight for the future of the EU funding programme LEADER
articles.summary: How much money will the European Union be able to make available in the future for regional projects in its member states? A changed geopolitical situation is creating new priorities, and rural regions in particular are looking with concern at the discussions on the next Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) of the EU. In Brussels, representatives from Nordrhein-Westfalen have now strongly advocated for the future of the LEADER funding program.
articles.content:
How much money will the European Union be able to make available in the future for regional projects in its member states? A changed geopolitical situation is creating new priorities, and rural regions in particular are looking with concern at the discussions on the next Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) of the EU. In Brussels, representatives from Nordrhein-Westfalen have now strongly advocated for the future of the LEADER funding program.

Brussels (enr) – From the president of the Deutscher Landfrauenverband to the vice-chairman of an Oldtimerfreunde association from the Sauerland: it was a broad coalition of actors in politics and society in North Rhine-Westphalia who campaigned in Brussels on Wednesday evening for a good future for the EU funding program LEADER.

LEADER has stood since 1991 for “Linking actions for the development of the rural economy” (in French: Liaison Entre Actions de Développement de l’Économie Rurale). The program supports, for example, village communities and associations in implementing projects on the ground – as an example, the Oldtimerfreunde from Hallenberg in the Sauerland presented how, with the help of EU funds, they were able to set up a carpentry and blacksmith’s workshop in their exhibition hall.

LEADER is “one of the absolutely central funding instruments for the development of rural regions,” said North Rhine-Westphalia’s Agriculture Minister Silke Gorißen (CDU). She pointed out that there are 2,700 regions with LEADER projects across Europe, 45 of them in North Rhine-Westphalia. Around 1,500 projects have been supported there over the past ten years, “mostly driven by great voluntary commitment. And every single one of these projects has very concretely led to a better quality of life in the villages.”

Christina Steinbicker, spokesperson for the Landesarbeitsgemeinschaft der NRW-LEADER-Regionen, emphasized that the people involved in the projects experience self-efficacy and thereby see: “We can make a difference, we are heard, our needs are perceived.” This also helps to ensure that tendencies in the anti-democratic sphere can be intercepted by the projects on the ground.

However, the negotiations currently pending in Brussels on the next Multiannual Financial Framework of the EU (Multiannual Financial Framework, MFF) for the years 2028 to 2034 have caused great concern among many stakeholders in the LEADER regions that significantly less money will be available for their measures in the future – because, for example, much more EU money is to be spent on strengthening security.

Agriculture Minister Rainer fears cannibalization

The German Federal Minister of Agriculture Alois Rainer (CSU) said he knew “that many are worried about the future of LEADER,” and he “feared – but it must not happen – a cannibalization of the funds.” The latest proposal from the EU Commission, which provides for a fixed minimum quota for funds from the national and regional partnership plans for rural regions, is “fundamentally to be welcomed,” but can “only be a starting point for the upcoming discussion.” Rainer also called for a significant simplification of the handling of funding in the LEADER program: “So that good ideas can grow, we need above all one thing: less bureaucracy.”

Specifically, there is the prospect that the share of financing for LEADER projects contributed from national funds could rise from 20 to 60 percent in economically strong regions – a development that would affect large parts of Germany. “That is of course considerable, and it would call many of these projects into question,” said Bernd Söntgerath, head of division in the Bundesministerium für Landwirtschaft, Ernährung und Heimat, who referred to the financial situation of the federal and state governments.

Martin Michalzik (CDU), former mayor of Wickede (Ruhr) and spokesperson for the chairs of the 45 LEADER regions in North Rhine-Westphalia, put it this way: “If a program is designed in such a way for the future that co-financing at the national level is to increase threefold, this will be understood by the actors on the ground as the termination of the program.”

The main addressee of all these remarks that evening was Oliver Sitar, director in the Directorate-General for Agriculture and Rural Development in the EU Commission, who was also on the podium and stated: “The importance of LEADER in Germany is obvious, also for us in Brussels.” The Commission continues to stand by LEADER.

However, the Member of the European Parliament Peter Liese (CDU) made it clear that, for him as well, the current MFF proposal must be significantly improved before the package is put to a vote in the European Parliament: “If it is not clear that rural areas will be substantially supported, then I will not agree – and many other colleagues in the European Parliament will not either.” (4 December)
articles.reasoning: The article highlights a significant and positive advocacy effort to secure future funding for the EU's LEADER program, which supports rural development projects across many regions, improving quality of life and fostering community engagement. The story focuses on a meaningful policy discussion with broad societal impact on rural communities across Europe, emphasizing democratic participation and local empowerment. While the outcome is still uncertain, the active efforts and recognition by EU officials represent hopeful progress for sustaining valuable rural development initiatives.
articles.personality_title: Rural regions unite to protect EU funding for local projects
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The European Union (EU) provides money to support projects in rural areas through a program called LEADER, which helps villages and communities improve their local economy and quality of life. The EU is now deciding how much money it will give for these projects in the future, but new priorities like security spending may reduce the funds for rural development.

**What happened** – Representatives from North Rhine-Westphalia, including politicians and community groups, gathered in Brussels to advocate strongly for the continuation and support of the LEADER program. They shared examples, such as a local group that used EU funds to create workshops for carpentry and blacksmithing, showing how these projects benefit rural communities. EU officials, including the Agriculture Minister and members of the European Parliament, listened and expressed support but also concerns about funding changes and bureaucracy.

**Impact** – LEADER supports about 2,700 regions across Europe, with 45 in North Rhine-Westphalia alone. It helps people in rural areas feel involved and effective in their communities, which also helps protect democracy by encouraging participation. The program has funded around 1,500 projects in the region over the last ten years, improving life in villages. If funding is cut or made harder to access, many projects could stop, which worries local leaders and communities.

**What's next step** – Negotiations on the EU’s budget for 2028 to 2034 are ongoing. Local representatives and EU politicians plan to keep working to ensure LEADER receives enough funding. They want to reduce complicated rules so more good ideas can succeed. The European Parliament will vote on the budget proposal, and some members have said they will not approve it unless rural areas get strong support.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Rural communities and EU officials are actively working together to secure future funding for the LEADER program, which plays a key role in supporting local projects and improving life in Europe’s countryside.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les régions rurales unies pour protéger le financement local de l'UE
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – L'Union européenne (UE) finance des projets dans les zones rurales grâce au programme LEADER, qui aide les villages et les communautés à améliorer leur économie locale et leur qualité de vie. L'UE doit décider combien d'argent elle accordera à ces projets à l'avenir, mais de nouvelles priorités comme la sécurité pourraient réduire ces fonds.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Des représentants de Rhénanie-du-Nord-Westphalie, dont des politiciens et des groupes communautaires, se sont réunis à Bruxelles pour défendre fortement la poursuite et le soutien du programme LEADER. Ils ont partagé des exemples, comme un groupe local ayant utilisé des fonds européens pour créer des ateliers de menuiserie et de forge, montrant comment ces projets profitent aux communautés rurales. Des responsables européens, y compris le ministre de l'Agriculture et des membres du Parlement européen, ont écouté et exprimé leur soutien tout en soulignant des inquiétudes sur les changements de financement et la bureaucratie.

**Impact** – LEADER soutient environ 2 700 régions en Europe, dont 45 en Rhénanie-du-Nord-Westphalie. Il aide les habitants des zones rurales à se sentir impliqués et efficaces dans leurs communautés, ce qui protège aussi la démocratie en encourageant la participation. Le programme a financé environ 1 500 projets dans la région au cours des dix dernières années, améliorant la vie dans les villages. Si le financement est réduit ou rendu plus difficile d'accès, beaucoup de projets pourraient s'arrêter, ce qui inquiète les responsables locaux et les communautés.

**Prochaine étape** – Les négociations sur le budget de l'UE pour 2028 à 2034 sont en cours. Les représentants locaux et les politiciens européens continueront à travailler pour garantir un financement suffisant pour LEADER. Ils souhaitent simplifier les règles afin que plus de bonnes idées puissent réussir. Le Parlement européen votera la proposition de budget, et certains membres ont déclaré qu'ils ne l'approuveraient pas sans un soutien fort aux zones rurales.

**En une phrase** – Les communautés rurales et les responsables de l'UE travaillent ensemble pour assurer le financement futur du programme LEADER, qui joue un rôle essentiel dans le soutien aux projets locaux et l'amélioration de la vie en campagne.
articles.personality_title_es: Regiones rurales se unen para proteger la financiación local de la UE

**Una frase clave** – Comunidades rurales y funcionarios de la UE trabajan juntos para asegurar el financiamiento futuro del programa LEADER, que es clave para apoyar proyectos locales y mejorar la vida en el campo europeo.

articles.title: Press release - EU wine sector: MEPs and Council agree on new rules to support producers
articles.summary: On Thursday, MEPs and Council reached a provisional deal on a new 'wine package', addressing challenges that wine producers face and unlocking market opportunities.Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development Source : © European Union, 2025 - EP
articles.content:
The negotiators agreed to ease and clarify the rules on de-alcoholised wines. The term “alcohol-free” accompanied by the expression “0.0%” could be used if the strength of the product does not exceed 0.05% volume. Products whose strength is equal to or above 0.5% volume and that are at least 30% below the alcoholic strength of the category of wine before de-alcoholisation should be labelled as “alcohol reduced”, the deal says.

More funds and flexibility for wine producers

In cases of severe natural disasters, weather events, plant disease outbreaks or the presence of a plant pest, winegrowers will have an additional year to plant or replant affected vines of wine grape varieties

Negotiators agreed to use EU funds for grubbing up. Thanks to MEPs, the national payment ceiling for wine distillation and green harvesting will be set at 25% of global available funds per member state.



Wine tourism and promotion for export

Producer organisations managing protected designations of origin and protected geographical indication initiatives will get additional support to promote wine tourism, MEPs and Council agreed. Finally, the new rules will allow for better EU funding of promotional campaigns for quality European wines in third countries. Thanks to Parliament’s negotiators, the EU will support up to 60% while Member states can add up to 30% for small and medium enterprises and 20% for bigger companies.in order to cover the cost of information and promotional measures, such as advertising, events, exhibitions and studies. The costs and promotion plan could be financed for three years, renewable twice by the same period for a total of nine years.



Quote

Rapporteur Esther Herranz García (EPP, Spain) said: “We are providing the sector with tools to tackle the profound crisis it is experiencing. These include measures to regulate supply in line with demand, such as the option of financing crisis measures, such as grubbing-up, with European funds, thereby ensuring equal opportunities for wine growers in the different Member States. We are also offering higher co-financing rates for measures for adapting to climate change. Finally, we have improved conditions for promotion outside the EU, which will allow for more stable and better targeted campaigns, and enhanced the conditions for wine tourism and the opportunities for diversification that it offers.”

Next steps

The provisional agreement needs to be approved by both Parliament and Council before the new rules can enter into force.
articles.reasoning: The article reports on new EU rules supporting wine producers through regulatory clarity, financial aid, and promotion efforts. These measures provide tangible benefits to a broad sector of agricultural producers across multiple countries, including support for adapting to climate change and disaster recovery. The story focuses on a single, meaningful policy change with clear positive impacts on the wine industry and rural economies, making it an inspiring example of targeted economic and environmental support.
articles.personality_title: EU agrees new rules to help wine producers grow and recover
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Wine producers in the European Union face challenges like natural disasters, plant diseases, and changing climate. To support them, EU lawmakers worked on new rules to improve the wine market and help producers recover.

**What happened** – On Thursday, Members of the European Parliament (MEPs) and the Council reached an agreement on a new 'wine package.' This deal sets clearer rules for labeling de-alcoholised wines, allows more time for replanting vineyards damaged by disasters, and provides extra funding for wine producers. It also supports wine tourism and promotional campaigns to sell EU wines outside Europe.

**Impact** – The new rules make it easier for producers to label alcohol-free and alcohol-reduced wines, which helps customers understand what they buy. Producers get more time and money to recover from bad weather or pests. Extra funds will help promote European wines globally and boost wine tourism, which can bring more visitors and money to rural areas.

**What's next step** – The agreement still needs final approval from the European Parliament and the Council. Once approved, the new rules will start helping wine producers across the EU.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The EU’s new wine rules offer clear support to wine producers through better labeling, financial aid, and promotion to strengthen the sector and rural communities.
articles.personality_title_fr: L'UE adopte de nouvelles règles pour soutenir les producteurs de vin
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les producteurs de vin dans l’Union européenne font face à des défis comme les catastrophes naturelles, les maladies des plantes et le changement climatique. Pour les aider, les législateurs européens ont travaillé sur de nouvelles règles pour améliorer le marché du vin et soutenir les producteurs.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Jeudi, les députés européens (MEP) et le Conseil sont parvenus à un accord sur un nouveau « paquet vin ». Cet accord clarifie les règles d’étiquetage des vins désalcoolisés, accorde plus de temps pour replanter les vignes endommagées par des catastrophes, et fournit des fonds supplémentaires aux producteurs. Il soutient aussi le tourisme viticole et les campagnes de promotion du vin européen à l’étranger.

**Impact** – Ces nouvelles règles facilitent l’étiquetage des vins sans alcool et à teneur réduite, ce qui aide les consommateurs à mieux comprendre leurs achats. Les producteurs bénéficient de plus de temps et d’argent pour se remettre des intempéries ou des parasites. Des fonds supplémentaires aideront à promouvoir les vins européens dans le monde et à développer le tourisme viticole, apportant plus de visiteurs et de revenus dans les zones rurales.

**Prochaine étape** – L’accord doit encore être approuvé définitivement par le Parlement européen et le Conseil. Une fois validées, ces nouvelles règles aideront les producteurs de vin dans toute l’UE.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Les nouvelles règles européennes offrent un soutien clair aux producteurs de vin grâce à un meilleur étiquetage, une aide financière et des actions de promotion pour renforcer le secteur et les communautés rurales.
articles.personality_title_es: La UE acuerda nuevas normas para apoyar a los productores de vino
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los productores de vino en la Unión Europea enfrentan desafíos como desastres naturales, enfermedades de las plantas y el cambio climático. Para ayudarlos, los legisladores europeos trabajaron en nuevas normas para mejorar el mercado del vino y apoyar a los productores.

Este acuerdo aclara las reglas para etiquetar vinos desalcoholizados, da más tiempo para replantar viñas dañadas por desastres y ofrece fondos extra para los productores. También apoya el turismo del vino y campañas de promoción para vender vinos europeos fuera de Europa.

**Impacto** – Las nuevas normas facilitan que los productores etiqueten los vinos sin alcohol y con alcohol reducido, ayudando a los clientes a entender mejor lo que compran. Los productores reciben más tiempo y dinero para recuperarse de mal tiempo o plagas. Los fondos adicionales ayudarán a promocionar los vinos europeos globalmente y a impulsar el turismo del vino, trayendo más visitantes y dinero a las zonas rurales.

**Próximo paso** – El acuerdo aún necesita la aprobación final del Parlamento Europeo y el Consejo. Una vez aprobado, las nuevas normas comenzarán a ayudar a los productores de vino en toda la UE.

**Resumen en una frase** – Las nuevas normas de la UE ofrecen apoyo claro a los productores de vino mediante mejor etiquetado, ayuda financiera y promoción para fortalecer el sector y las comunidades rurales.

articles.title: Žiláková: The EU Council is pushing for mandatory technical inspections of older cars every two years
articles.summary: State Secretary of the Ministry of Transport of the Slovak Republic Denisa Žiláková claims that the Council of the EU has managed to push through that technical inspections of older cars are more in favor of people.
articles.content:
State Secretary of the Ministry of Transport of the Slovak Republic Denisa Žiláková claims that the Council of the EU has managed to push through that technical inspections of older cars are more in favor of people.

Brussels – The European Commission (EC) has acknowledged the arguments of EU member states that for cars older than ten years, the technical inspection should take place once every two years and not every year. State Secretary of the Ministry of Transport of the Slovak Republic Denisa Žiláková said this in Brussels on Thursday after the meeting of the EU Council for Transport and Energy, reports the TASR correspondent.

Denisa Žiláková recalled that the ministers discussed several legislative proposals from the European Commission, and she considers the proposal to amend the regulation on the technical inspection of passenger vehicles to be the most important. According to her, this is good news for Slovakia as well, because the European Commission initially submitted a proposal for the technical inspection of this type of vehicle to be carried out every year.

“This did not fully suit the Slovak Republic and other member states, because it would mean a loss of time and would affect the wallets of Slovak citizens. Slovakia, through the Ministry of Transport, fought against this proposal and succeeded. There were, of course, several member states that were not satisfied with this proposal,” she described the situation.

On the table is a compromise proposal that technical inspections of vehicles older than 10 years should be once every two years

In practice, this means that there is a compromise proposal on the table for technical inspections to be carried out once every two years, as has been the case until now. The final wording of the revised regulation on technical inspections will be drawn up in trilogues, that is, negotiations between the EU Council, the European Commission and the European Parliament.

Žiláková welcomed the fact that a proposal for digital cross-border cooperation in this area has been created, which will speed up the exchange of information between member countries. She pointed out that Slovakia, like other countries, does not yet have such a digital system, and therefore welcomes the draft regulation that requires it to be created.

She specified that regarding technical inspections, the EU Council approved, for example, that a citizen of one member country who studies or lives in another EU member state can have the technical inspection of their vehicle carried out abroad. This type of inspection is valid for a period of six months. The third part of the amendment to the regulation on motor vehicles concerned, according to her, measures that prevent unauthorized interference with vehicles, which Slovaks know under the term “odometer rollback” on vehicles. Such practices are to be prevented by the amended EU regulation. (4 December)

articles.personality_title: EU agrees on two-year technical inspections for older cars to ease costs and improve cooperation
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The European Union is updating rules about how often cars older than ten years need to pass technical inspections. These checks make sure vehicles are safe and meet environmental standards.

**What happened** – The EU Council agreed that instead of yearly inspections, cars older than ten years will be checked every two years. This decision came after talks involving Slovakia and other member countries, which argued that yearly checks would be too costly and time-consuming for car owners. The final rules will be decided soon in further meetings involving the EU Council, Commission, and Parliament.

**Impact** – This change helps car owners save time and money while keeping safety standards. It also introduces a digital system for sharing inspection information across EU countries, making it easier for people who live or study abroad to get their cars checked. Additionally, the new rules will fight against illegal tampering with vehicle mileage, protecting buyers from fraud.

**What's next step** – The EU will finalize the updated rules in upcoming negotiations. Countries will then work on creating the digital system to connect inspection records across borders. After that, citizens can expect simpler and clearer processes when getting their cars inspected, even if they move between EU countries.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The EU’s new plan to inspect older cars every two years aims to balance safety, save money, and improve cooperation across member countries.
articles.personality_title_fr: L’UE adopte un contrôle technique bisannuel pour les voitures anciennes afin de réduire les coûts et faciliter la coopération
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – L’Union européenne met à jour les règles concernant la fréquence des contrôles techniques pour les voitures de plus de dix ans. Ces contrôles garantissent la sécurité et le respect des normes environnementales.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Le Conseil de l’UE a convenu que les voitures de plus de dix ans seront contrôlées tous les deux ans au lieu d’une fois par an. Cette décision fait suite à des discussions avec la Slovaquie et d’autres pays membres, qui estimaient que des contrôles annuels seraient trop coûteux et longs pour les propriétaires. Les règles finales seront bientôt décidées lors de nouvelles réunions entre le Conseil, la Commission et le Parlement européen.

**Impact** – Ce changement aide les conducteurs à économiser du temps et de l’argent tout en maintenant les normes de sécurité. Il introduit aussi un système numérique pour partager les informations des contrôles entre pays de l’UE, ce qui facilitera les démarches pour les personnes vivant ou étudiant à l’étranger. De plus, les nouvelles règles lutteront contre la falsification du kilométrage, protégeant ainsi les acheteurs.

**Prochaine étape** – L’UE finalisera les règles mises à jour lors de prochaines négociations. Les pays travailleront ensuite à la création du système numérique pour connecter les dossiers de contrôle techniques transfrontaliers. Les citoyens pourront alors bénéficier de procédures plus simples et claires pour faire contrôler leurs voitures, même en changeant de pays.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Le nouveau plan de l’UE pour un contrôle technique bisannuel des voitures anciennes vise à concilier sécurité, économies et meilleure coopération entre pays membres.
articles.personality_title_es: La UE acuerda inspecciones técnicas cada dos años para coches antiguos para reducir costos y mejorar cooperación
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La Unión Europea está actualizando las normas sobre la frecuencia con la que los coches de más de diez años deben pasar inspecciones técnicas. Estas revisiones garantizan que los vehículos sean seguros y cumplan con estándares ambientales.

**Qué pasó** – El Consejo de la UE acordó que, en lugar de inspecciones anuales, los coches de más de diez años serán revisados cada dos años. Esta decisión vino después de conversaciones con Eslovaquia y otros países miembros, que argumentaron que las inspecciones anuales serían demasiado costosas y consumirían mucho tiempo para los propietarios. Las reglas finales se decidirán pronto en negociaciones entre el Consejo, la Comisión y el Parlamento Europeo.

**Impacto** – Este cambio ayuda a los dueños de coches a ahorrar tiempo y dinero mientras se mantienen los estándares de seguridad. También introduce un sistema digital para compartir información de inspecciones entre países de la UE, facilitando a quienes viven o estudian en el extranjero realizar sus revisiones. Además, las nuevas reglas combatirán el fraude en el odómetro, protegiendo a los compradores.

**Próximo paso** – La UE finalizará las normas actualizadas en próximas negociaciones. Luego, los países trabajarán en crear el sistema digital para conectar los registros de inspecciones entre fronteras. Después, los ciudadanos podrán esperar procesos más simples y claros para inspeccionar sus coches, incluso si se mudan entre países.

**Resumen en una frase** – El nuevo plan de la UE para inspeccionar coches antiguos cada dos años busca equilibrar la seguridad, ahorrar dinero y mejorar la cooperación entre países miembros.
